title: Tuncurry - Forster Gold ready for first championship against Lake Cathie | Great Lakes Advocate
body_text:
TUNCURRY-Forster Gold will go into uncharted territory when they tackle Lake Cathie in the Football Mid North Coast women's zone championship match at Taree's Omaru Park on Friday night.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
This will be the first time the zone has played championship matches in the senior grades.
Gold earned the right to contest the match by scoring a 1-0 win over arch rivals Cundletown Jets after nearly 100 minutes of the Southern League grand final at Tuncurry.
Lake Cathie are the northern champions.
Gold captain, Meaghan Lambert admits she knows little about Friday night's opponents.
"They're apparently a young bunch of girls and most used to play in the WPL,'' Lambert said.
"So we don't really know what we're up against, but we're looking forward to the challenge.''
The Gold-Jets grand final was typical of matches between the two sides, hard, close and physical.
"It was 0-0 at fulltime and we went to extra time.
"Then we scored within the last four minutes to get the win.
"It didn't come to a penalty shoot out, so we were happy about that.''
Sophie France broke the deadlock with the goal.
Lambert said backs, Miller Crabb and Abby O'brien were outstanding.
"Our backline this year was phenomenal,'' she added.
Kalani Morris was called into the goal keeping duties as the side's regular keeper was unavailable.
Keeping the Jets scoreless is never easy, so that was a great effort.
- Captain, Meaghan Lambert
"Kalani is unstoppable when she's keeping,'' Lambert said.
"Our defence has been good all year and we were strong there again.''
"Keeping the Jets scoreless is never easy, so that was a great effort.''
However, Tuncurry-Forster's B-grade side lost the grand final to Wingham by a goal.
"They did sensationally to get there,'' Lambert said.
"Pete Ragno has done a great job with them.''
Lambert said the decision by Football Mid North Coast to divide the competition into A and B-grades after one round proved beneficial. A record 14 sides took part this season.
The zone hopes this will be the case from the start of next season, with clubs possibly nominating for a grade.
"It would be a bit intimidating for some of the teams when they play the top sides and we don't want to go out and annihilate another side,'' Lambert said.
Lambert is a 10 year veteran with the club and thinks she's been captain for the past five or six.
"I think we've won five or six comps,'' she said.
"The majority of players will be back next year. We'll lose a few of the younger girls who will go to uni, but we regenerate pretty well.''
